name: Business
intro: Zakat on business assets is due on trade goods held for sale, provided their value exceeds the nisab for a full lunar year. This ensures business wealth is purified and benefits society.

evidences.text: O you who have believed, spend from the good things which you have earned...
No zakat is due on less than five awsuq of dates, nor less than five camels, nor less than five uqiyah of silver.

conditions: Owns trade goods above the nisab for one lunar year (hawl).
Goods are held for sale, not personal use.
calculation: Value your inventory at market price. Add receivables, subtract payables. If above nisab, pay 2.5%.
example: Example: Inventory value is $10,000. Receivables: $2,000. Payables: $1,000. Net: $11,000. If nisab is $4,000, pay 2.5% of $11,000 = $275.
madhhabNotes: All schools: Zakat is due on trade goods at market value after one lunar year. Debts are subtracted.

faq.q: How do I value trade goods?

faq.a: Yes, subtract payables from assets. See: https://islamqa.info/en/answers/22449/zakaah-on-goods-prepared-for-trade

faq.q: Is zakat due on fixed assets?
faq.a: No, only on goods for sale. See: https://islamqa.info/en/answers/22449/zakaah-on-goods-prepared-for-trade
